results.title: Joan
results.creator_credit: Department of Social Security and Film Australia
results.brief_description: One of a series of films created originally for day-time television panel discussions to introduce to the public the range of social services available from Government and other agencies. This programme deals with the problems of unmarried mothers and in particular, with Joan, who worked at an assortment of jobs in order to keep her daughter. The film looks back at her life and at how she and her daughter have come through difficult years. It also highlights a social welfare group known as CHUM - Care and Help for Unmarried Mothers - where social interaction and support are available for women of all ages who are single mothers.

results.title: A Kibbutz
results.brief_description: Gives a brief history of the establishment of the kibbutz. Describes community organisation, and the changing role of women on the kibbutz. Shows the progress of a child through the system. Discussion ensues when two of the haberim wish to leave the kibbutz - problems and advantages are aired.

results.title: Sad song of yellow skin
results.creator_credit: Michael Rubbo, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film about the people of Saigon as seen through the experience of three young American journalists who, in 1970, explored in their own way the consequences of war and of the American presence. It is not a film about the Vietnam war, or the rights or wrongs of it, but about the people who lived on the fringe of battle. The views of the city are arresting; but away from the shrines and the open-air markets lay another city, swollen with refugees and war orphans, where every inch of habitable space was covered. (Seven awards, including: Melbourne, Toronto, Robert J. Flaherty.)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Rubbo, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Female cycle
results.brief_description: A simple animated explanation of menstruation. It shows how ovaries produce eggs, one of which moves to the surface each month and enters the fallopian tube to travel to the uterus. Secretions from these organs enter the blood and prepare the uterus for the fertilised egg and cause a period.

results.title: The Magistrates
results.brief_description: A re-enactment of parts of a typical Monday morning’s proceedings of a city magistrates’ court in New South Wales (called Petty Sessions in that State). Also includes visits and extensive interviews with justices and lawyers about New South Wales county court system and justice system. Presented by Gerald Stone.

results.title: Out of slavery: 1619-1860
results.creator_credit: Alvin Yudkoff, Milton Meltzer and McGraw-Hill Films
results.brief_description: Effective use of illustrations and still photographs, coupled with powerful music, to describe the period from the beginning of the slave trade with Africa to the election of Abraham Lincoln. Deals with the role of the War of Independence and the Declaration of Independence in the abolition of slavery. Also the growth of the southern cotton industry, underground railway, and northern abolitionists. Narrated by James Earl Jones. Suitable for upper primary and secondary school levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alvin Yudkoff, Milton Meltzer and McGraw-Hill Films

results.title: Mr Koumal flies like a bird
results.creator_credit: Gene Deitch, Sim Productions and Studio Animovaneho Filmu
results.brief_description: Mr Koumal has his heart set on flying like a bird. His repeated attempts end in disaster. Ultimately the irrepressible Mr Koumal finds a way out. He sells the feathers he has used for wings to an Indian head-dress shop.

results.title: A meal at Francis' = Un repas chez Francis
results.creator_credit: John Seabourne and Institut für Film und Bild
results.brief_description: An American girl and her French friend have lunch together in Paris. They look for a restaurant and then the American girl is shown how to order a meal, name foods and beverages, the French girl also explains French eating habits all carried out in simple slowly-spoken French.

results.title: Maria of the Pueblos
results.brief_description: Centres on the life of Maria Martinez, who is probably the world’s most successful Indian potter. Tells how Maria accidentally rediscovered the secret of recreating iridescent black pottery, and unselfishly shard it to life her village out of poverty.

results.title: Phoebe
results.creator_credit: George Kaczender, Julian Biggs and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film story exploring the state of mind of a teenage girl when she learns she is pregnant. The film slips in and out of the present, past and future in a way that communicates her feelings in an almost subjective way. Her need to tell her parents, her boyfriend, her school principal, and to find some help in her predicament is the heart of the film. Cast: Bernard Blumer, Yael Brandeis, John Kastner, Dona Saunders, Sandra Scott, Kay Tremblay. (Awards: Five including Montreal; New York)
